docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists already have suggested that eating chocolate may make people happy. Now they say men who indulge in chocolates may live longer. A study of 7,841 Harvard male graduates found that chocolate and candy eaters, regardless of how voracious their appetite for goodies, lived almost a year longer than those who abstained.

headline.main: Heaven! Longer Life and Chocolate, Too

docs.abstract: Study of Harvard graduates suggests that men who eat chocolate and candy live almost a year longer than those who abstain; moderate eaters do best, but even the immoderate do better than those who eat none (S)
docs.snippet: Scientists already have suggested that eating chocolate may make people happy. Now they say men who indulge in chocolates may live longer.    A study of 7,841 Harvard male graduates found that chocolate and candy eaters, regardless of how voracious...

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute has created a new Web site to help physicians, researchers and asthma patients. The Asthma Management Model System was started this month and is designed to keep researchers, health care professionals and the public abreast of developments in asthma management. The system -- at www.nhlbi.nih.gov -- consists of Web site links for research, education and communications. The research link brings users to an interactive search engine that ties them to scientific databases like Medline and Crisp. The education link provides access to an electronic library, patient education programs and medical education programs for physicians. The communications link connects to the Web master, provides access to asthma chat rooms and on-line forums, and invites users to register for updates.

headline.main: Managing Asthma With Aid of Computer

docs.abstract: National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute creates Web site to help physicians, researchers and asthma patients; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of new procedures and products are becoming available for whitening teeth, but some authorities question the effectiveness and safety of some of the items. Manufacturers insist that the products are both safe and effective. Whitening solutions with high concentrations of hydrogen peroxide -- 30 percent to 35 percent -- have been available in dentists' offices for years for teeth stained by food, coffee, tea, tobacco or other substances. Initially, the solutions required meticulous preparation and this, coupled with their unpredictability, limited their popularity.

headline.main: Caution Urged When Seeking Whiter Teeth

docs.abstract: FDA reports that questions are still being raised about effectiveness and safety of some teeth-whitening procedures and products on the market; Dr Clifford W Whall Jr of American Dental Association says that in-office bleaches have long record of safety, but that it is too soon for long-term conclusions on laser or at-home procedures; animal studies suggest that high concentrations of hydrogen peroxide, the whitening agent, can kill gum tissue or damage the teeth if done improperly (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has found that Benjamin Franklin might have had it all wrong when he advised early to bed and early to rise. Night owls, British researchers have found, are just as likely as early-rising larks to be healthy, wealthy and wise. ''We found no evidence that following Franklin's advice about going to bed and getting up early was associated with any health, socioeconomic or cognitive advantage,'' Dr. Catharine Gale and Dr. Christopher Martyn reported in the current issue of The British Medical Journal.

headline.main: Night Owls Now Getting the Worms

docs.abstract: British researchers find no support for Benjamin Franklin's dictum that early to bed and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise; find that late retirers are actually wealthier than early retirers; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study has found that Benjamin Franklin might have had it all wrong when he advised early to bed and early to rise. Night owls, British researchers have found, are just as likely as early-rising larks to be healthy, wealthy and wise.    ''We...

docs.lead_paragraph: The final fact of life is that when you die, a doctor is required to fill out your death certificate, specifying the cause of death. Assigning a cause is more than an exercise in morbid curiosity. The certificate has important legal and social purposes. For families of the deceased, the certificates can affect health and finances. For policy makers, the documents provide information to track national trends in diseases and form a basis for setting spending priorities. For researchers, the information is crucial to scientific studies.

headline.main: Getting It Right on the Facts of Death

docs.abstract: New analysis of data from Framingham Heart Study in Massachusetts confirms that doctors too frequently assign wrong cause of death on death certificate; this has serious consequences not only for health and finances of the deceased's family, but also for national health policy and health spending, which should be based on accurate documentation; doctors are given spotty training in assigning a cause of death and usually learn what they learn informally during residency training; family pressures, even hospital billing practices, can influence what is listed as a cause of death; graph (M)
docs.snippet: The final fact of life is that when you die, a doctor is required to fill out your death certificate, specifying the cause of death.    Assigning a cause is more than an exercise in morbid curiosity. The certificate has important legal and social...

docs.lead_paragraph: Last-minute holiday shoppers, take note: Many toys are not safe. In 1995, the last year for which statistics were available, Americans bought 2.6 billion toys and games. And according to National Safe Kids, an organization for the prevention of childhood injury, about 121,000 children ages 14 and under were treated in emergency rooms for toy-related injuries. Nearly 60 percent were 4 or younger.

headline.main: Careful Shopping for Safer, Saner Toys

docs.abstract: National Safe Kids, an organization for prevention of childhood injury, reports that about 121,000 children ages 14 and under were treated in emergency rooms for toy-related injuries in 1995; offers guidelines for selecting age-appropriate toys; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cappy is a lovable but naughty 32-pound cocker spaniel with an insatiable appetite. So it should not have surprised his owners when, two days before Christmas, he raided the wrapped gifts under the tree and ate an entire 12-ounce box of chocolate-covered coffee beans. His owners returned from a holiday party to find him racing about the house, his heart pounding rapidly. An emergency visit to an all-night veterinary clinic revealed that in his haste to devour the treats before he was discovered, he had swallowed the beans whole, avoiding more serious consequences like seizures from the stimulants in the dark chocolate and coffee. Cappy was lucky. Many a pet dog and cat has suffered far more disastrous health problems from holiday-related hazards, and more than a few have died, casting an unshakable pall over the whole season for those who loved them. Dr. John Saidla, director of continuing education at Cornell University's College of Veterinary Medicine, said he spent his saddest Christmas trying in vain to save a young dog hit by a car when it dashed across the street after the family children, who had gone to inspect a neighbor's new bike. The dog had been a gift to the children after their father was killed in a plane crash on Christmas two years earlier.

headline.main: When Holiday Treasures Pose Dangers to House Pets

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column warns that pets are especially vulnerable to sickness or injury during the holidays; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: From the very first hours of the AIDS crisis -- especially the confusing interval between 1981, when the first cases were reported, and 1982, when the mysterious blight was given a name -- there have been wild conspiracy theories. One theory fingered the Central Intelligence Agency for a failed biological war against Cuba that inadvertently backfired (scuba-diving operatives were said to have fumbled a lethal vial and broken it against a rock in Haiti). Another theory held that this was no new virus at all, but African swine fever, a deadly danger being hushed up by the powerful pork industry. Still another theory was that the virus had been engineered by Government scientists.

headline.main: Challenging the Conventional Stance on AIDS

docs.abstract: Large number of African-Americans remain skeptical of the Government's and scientific community's explanation of AIDS epidemic; one survey found that 18 percent of blacks believe HIV is an engineered microbe and that nearly 10 percent believe that AIDS is part of a plot to kill blacks; speakers at recent AIDS forum in Harlem sponsored by Rev Al Sharpton and National Action Network deliver a score of assaults on AIDS orthodoxy; photo (M)
